title: Scene Chronology

author: Kevin Matzen, Department of Computer Science, Cornell University

segmentation: I'm kind of medicine and today I'll be presenting our paper titled Scene Chronology.
This is joint work with my advisor, Noah Snavely at Cornell University.
In the last several years, we've made huge progress in the field of 3D reconstruction, both in terms of quality as well as scalability.
In fact, we can now reconstruct entire cities, such as the Old Town of Dubrovnik, shown here from Internet photos or.
Or even use all of the Google Street View imagery to construct a planet scale reconstruction here.
Klinger at all shows Zoom in all the way from the planet level to the street level of Sydney.
So if it's possible to do this at the planet skill, does that mean we've solved the reconstruction problem?
One common assumption in these works is that the scene or the background is more or less static.
However, the reality of our world doesn't match this representation as nicely as we might hope.
We believe that key on going challenge in 3D modeling will be reconstructing dynamic scenes.
Cities are a great example of where the static is.
Option is broken here.
I'm showing you Times Square from Google Street View time machine.
As we move forward in time, we can see billboards sign.
And business is changing.
These changes happen on many different timescales.
Some, even on a daily basis.
Now the reason why I'm showing you time machine is because you could claim that this is algorithm 0 for representing dynamic scenes.
This is 1 possible representation, but it's very limited.
What is the right way to model such time varying scenes and what data do we need to compute these models?
So what might what might we want out of a 40 model?
We'd like to have richly reconstructed spaces in which we can move around and explore, and we'd like to be able to capture fine grained temporal structure on the order of weeks, or just days.
We'd also like to enable visualizations where we can dial back to any point in time.
We were particularly inspired by Schindler and Alerts 40 City project, which I'll talk more about later.
A key question to ask is what input data should we use?
Street View offers high quality pose but has very low temporal resolution.
In fact, Times Square had only six snapshots publicly available as of today.
Webcams offer a high temporal resolution, but are fixed and therefore have low viewpoint variation.
And user generated content in the form of Internet photo collections can be massive in scale but often lacks structure.
We need massive collections in order to expand the space of three depots in time, so.
We chose to use unstructured Internet photo collections as the input for this work.
In this work, we incorporate timestamps in order to build a 40 representation for a scene.
Unfortunately, these timestamps can be corrupted with random or systematic errors.
For example, some really silly things can happen.
Photographers may never set the Clock on their cameras or photo sharing services may report the date uploaded timestamp instead of data taken, especially for older photographs.
Therefore, the algorithms I talk about today must be robust despite temporal outliers.
We also lack the ability to control when and where people take photos, so spatial and temporal sampling can be irregular.
Finally, we decided that we must scale this system to millions of photos, and when I say millions, I don't mean that's an arbitrary goal we chose because it sounded big.
I mean, that's the size of the collections we obtained today with public APIs.
Ideally we want to scale the system to all photos to densely sample the 40 space of views.
Each of these photos has something unique to say, so we should use as many as possible.
We believe this 40 problem to be a key problem, but 40 modeling has received much less attention than his three counterpart in recent years.
We were particularly inspired by Schindler and layered who recovered the history of buildings in the city by examining occlusion relations.
Other work listed here uses change detection to understand the evolution of the scene.
For one key difference between related work in our own is scale.
We're using several orders of magnitude more data to capture a finer grained representation.
So we decided to rethink the algorithms we should use.
To overcome these challenges, we present a new approach for reconstructing the chronology of a scene from millions of unstructured photos.
We provide a method to robustly estimate per point time intervals for three point cloud, and we provide a method to segment that now 40 point cloud into temporally coherent components.
And finally, both methods are scalable to millions of photos.

I'm going to explain some of the representations that we explored, and then I'm going to talk about how we compute them.
